quoteFirst: Yours has come, my guest, at precisely this moment. It is, if my watch tells me the truth, five and
quoteLast: . It is the last day of April. The year you know. You have exactly one minute to decide whether you will live a short time longer, or whether you will on this last day of April, and before--say, a quarter to four, make that little journey the nature of which you and I have discussed more than once.
title: The Vanished Messenger
author: Oppenheim, E. Phillips (Edward Phillips), 1866-1946

quoteFirst: The 'Héros' continued in her position, giving and receiving a severe fire for nine minutes, and then stood on, greatly damaged, to attack the 'Monmouth,' at that time engaged with another of the enemy's ships, making room for the ships in his rear to come up to the attack of our centre, where the engagement was hottest. At three the 'Monmouth' had her mizzen-mast shot away, and in a few minutes her mainmast, and bore out of the line to leeward (C, c); and at
quoteLast: the wind unexpectedly continuing far northerly without any sea-breeze, and being careful not to entangle our ships with the land, I made signal to wear and haul by the wind in a line-of-battle on the larboard tack, still engaging the enemy.
title: The Influence of Sea Power Upon History, 1660-1783
author: Mahan, A. T. (Alfred Thayer), 1840-1914

quoteFirst: _9th October_: _
quoteLast: , two kilomètres from Estaires, scouting amongst beetroot fields._--Has the supreme moment come? A little while ago I firmly believed it had; now I am out of my reckoning, so incomprehensible and widespread is the struggle which surrounds us.

quoteFirst: Now Lady Tasker was seventy, and, with the exception of the Zoo, a place she visited from time to time with troops of turbulent great-nephews, the whole of North London was a sort of Camden Town to her, that is to say, she had no objection to its existence so long as it wasn't troublesome. It was half-past three when she said as much to the Highgate policeman, who up to that time had been an ordinary easy-going Conservative; by five-and-
quoteLast: she had made of him a fuming Radical. He was saying something about South Square and Merton Lane.
title: Gray youth: The story of a very modern courtship and a very modern marriage
author: Onions, Oliver, 1873-1961

quoteFirst: Clif went out and perched himself near the bottom of the flight. It was not so warm now. He looked at his watch.
quoteLast: . His father would be somewhere about Hartford, he guessed; that is, barring trouble with that soft tire. He hoped there had been no trouble, for his father usually left tire changing to him. Clif smiled.
title: The Fighting Scrub
author: Barbour, Ralph Henry, 1870-1944; Rahn, A. D. [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: The Admiral made the Bedford's signal to get into her station. One of the French ships struck to the van. Coming up with the enemy's fleet, beat to quarters.
quoteLast: we began to engage some of the enemy's ships to leeward on contrary tacks. At ten minutes past four, having passed them, ceased firing and hauled up the courses; wore ship ahead of the Formidable two of the enemy's ships struck their colours.
